bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to D.J. Withington, January 22, 1941

div1.p: Hench suggests meeting with Cornwell and Withington to discuss a possible future painting to be included in their series entitled "Pioneers of American Medicine." He offers to present them with his research on the Yellow Fever Commission. Hench discusses his memorial plans in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to D.J. Withington, January 22, 1941
div1.opener:
leave on desk.
January 22, 1941
Mr. D. J. Withington
John Wyeth and Brother, Inc.
1600 Arch Street
Philadelphia, Pa.
My dear Mr. Withington:
div1.p:
I appreciate greatly your letter of January 9, 1941. The second
picture of “Beaumont and St. Martin” (framed) arrived in fine order and is now
in my office. I am sorry not to have received from you the picture of Osler
similarly signed by the author, but I have the one you sent me already framed
in my office. I think these are fine paintings.

I am very glad that you and Mr. Cornwell have not concluded your
plans regarding the Reed painting, and would appreciate giving you some data
based on three years' investigation of the Walter Reed Army Yellow Fever Board.
By separate post, I am sending you an article of mine on the subject which I
gave recently at the dedication of the Lazear Memorial Building at Washington
and Jefferson College. I would be indeed glad to meet you and Mr. Kellogg,
and discuss my investigations in detail, and partly in confidence.

Mr. Cornwell is quite correct. Dr. Carlos Finlay did play quite
an important part and I think deserves a place in the painting, but others are
more important. To portray the subject adequately yet present a portrait that
is historically accurate will be impossible. At no one time, when the crucial
experiments were being made, were all of the principal participants together.
I think that Mr. Cornwell must be allowed some license, but as the painting will
involve not only some medical accuracy but will involve the relationship between
the governments and medical professions of Cuba and America, I am very anxious
to make some suggestions which I know will please all concerned. Perhaps I am
anticipating myself in informing you confidentially that I am trying to arrange
the erection of a suitable memorial building to house the small building which
is all that remains of Camp Lazear. Such a memorial building could be placed in
the most suitable spot in Havana. It is my hope that the original painting
might be permanently loaned by your company to this museum, erected to commemorate
the conquest of yellow fever.

I expect to be here until the middle of March when I will return
to Havana to conclude my investigations. I should like to spend at least a half
day with you. Personally, a Monday might be the best day for me, although if you
prefer to spend an evening, we could spend a whole evening going over the matter.
If this is not suitable, if you will let me know a few days ahead of time I can
Mr. D. J. Withington
- 2 -
January 22, 1941
re-arrange my work so that I can give you a whole morning or a whole afternoon.
I hope you are not coming out just to see me. Nevertheless, I am able to give
you much information that is not contained in the little brochure sent by
separate post.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
